The_Harters:
{{Short description|American country music trio}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = The Harters | image = | alias = SEVEN | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Arizona]], U.S. | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | years_active = 2005, 2009{{spaced ndash}}2011 | label = [[Bigger Picture Music Group]] | past_members = Leslie Harter
[[J. Michael Harter|Michael Harter]]
Scott Harter }} '''The Harters''' were an American country music trio based in [[Arizona]]. It was composed of lead singer Leslie Harter and her brothers, [[J. Michael Harter|Michael]] and Scott. The trio released its debut single, "Jenny," in early 2010 and charted with it on ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]]. ==Biography== Brothers Michael and Scott Harter, and their sister Leslie, were involved in various other musical endeavors before forming the band together. Michael had moved to [[Nashville]] to become a country songwriter/performer, recording one album for [[Broken Bow Records]] in 2002 under the name [[J. Michael Harter]]. Scott went to school in San Diego where he played in [[alternative rock]] bands. Leslie remained in Arizona where she decided at age 18 that she was going to pursue a career in music. In 2005, the Harters recorded one single, "Drunk Chick," under the name SEVEN, with [[David Malloy]] as producer.{{cite web |url=http://www.musiccitynews.com/clients4.php |title=MCN Country Music - SEVEN |access-date=16 March 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061220044448/http://musiccitynews.com/clients4.php |archive-date=20 December 2006 |work=Music City News}} After deciding that they would begin performing together, they began recording videos of themselves on [[YouTube]].{{cite web |url = http://www.theinsider.com/videos/top |title = Top Videos |access-date = 12 July 2009 |publisher = CBS Interactive Inc. }} They were discovered by producer [[Keith Stegall]], best known for his work as [[Alan Jackson]]'s producer.{{cite web |url = http://www.musicrow.com/2009/03/sony-atv-signs-stegall/ |title = Sony ATV Signs Stegall |date = 23 March 2009 |access-date = 3 August 2009 |publisher = MusicRow }} The Harters also caught the attention of [[Adam Gregory]], with whom they collaborated{{cite web |url = http://www.casttv.com/video/iew1gg/adam-gregory-rehearses-on-the-bus-with-the-harters-video |title = Adam Gregory Rehearses on the Bus with The Harters |access-date = 3 August 2009 |publisher = CastTV }} when the two acts shared the stage for a children's charity show.{{cite web |url = http://www.countryhound.com/Monster-Trucks-and-Country-Music-Team-Up |title = Monster Trucks and Country Music Team Up |access-date = 3 August 2009 |publisher = CountryHound }} The band was subsequently asked to open a series of shows for [[Josh Turner]].{{cite web |url = http://www.nashvillelifestyles.com/apps/pbcs.dll/gallery?Site=DN&Date=20090730&Category=NL&ArtNo=907300802&Ref=PH&Params=Itemnr=16 |title = The HOT List |access-date = 3 August 2009 |publisher = The Tennessean }} The Harters were also featured in [[People (magazine)|People.com]]'s July 2009 Photo Special.{{cite web |url = http://www.people.com/people/gallery/0,,20294269_20650941,00.html#20650941 |title = Download This (Free!): Hot Country Songs! |access-date = 10 August 2009 |publisher = Time Inc. }} The Harters made two songs available for free download on its website, including the debut single "Jenny."{{cite web |url = http://www.nashvillepost.com/news/2009/7/27/on_music_row_bigger_picture_brings_topspin_to_town |title = On Music Row: Bigger Picture brings Topspin to town |access-date = 3 August 2009 |publisher = NashvillePost.com }} Scott and Michael began writing the song five years before its release, and completed it with assistance from Malloy and Brad Irby.{{cite journal|date=29 March 2010|title=Who's New|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=17|issue=13|page=17|issn=1074-3235}} This song debuted at number 54 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts dated for the week ending March 20, 2010{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1633832/billy-currington-trumps-josh-turner-lady-antebellum-raves-on.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317142914/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1633832/billy-currington-trumps-josh-turner-lady-antebellum-raves-on.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 17, 2010|title=Billy Currington Trumps Josh Turner, Lady Antebellum Raves On|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=13 March 2010|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|access-date=26 April 2010}} and peaked at number 53.{{cite magazine|url={{BillboardURLbyName|artist=the harters|chart=all}}|title=Chart history for The Harters|magazine=Billboard|access-date=8 September 2010}} The album's second single "If I Run" released to country radio in 2011. That same year, the trio toured with [[Alan Jackson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/01/06/the-harters-alan-jackson-canada-tour/ |title=The Harters to Join Alan Jackson on Canadian Tour Dates |website=Theboot.com |access-date=4 April 2020}} ==Critical reception== Karlie Justus of Engine 145 gave "If I Run" a "thumbs up", comparing Leslie's voice to that of [[Trisha Yearwood]] and praising the lyrics.{{cite web |url=http://www.engine145.com/the-harters-if-i-run/ |title=The Harters - "If I Run" - Engine 145 |website= |access-date=3 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218105007/http://www.engine145.com/the-harters-if-i-run/ |archive-date=18 December 2014 |url-status=dead}} Giving favorable singles to both singles, Bobby Peacock of Roughstock praised the "clever turns of phrase" and melody of "Jenny",{{cite web |url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/the-harters-jenny- |title=The Harters - "Jenny" | Roughstock.com |website= |access-date=3 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323192937/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/the-harters-jenny- |archive-date=23 March 2010 |url-status=dead}} and the "uncluttered" production of "If I Run". He compared the latter song to [[The Band Perry]].{{cite web |url=http://www.roughstock.com/blog/the-harters-if-i-run- |title=The Harters - "If I Run" | New Country Music, Listen to Songs & Video | Roughstock.com |website= |access-date=3 January 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029050017/http://www.roughstock.com/blog/the-harters-if-i-run- |archive-date=29 October 2010 |url-status=dead}} ==Discography== ===Extended plays=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:14em;"| Title ! style="width:20em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Family.
